Issues.Title: View Encapsulation CSS with id
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 feature request
View Encapsulation only works with normal CSS classes
When I set 
#id-abc {font-size: 13px;} or h1.title { font-size: 13px};
Angular will not generate to [ng_content], above classes will be global ones.
Any suggestions for me, many thanks!

### Relevant Package
angular: 8.0.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "View Encapsulation CSS with id " (#34075)

Issues.Title: ci: disable renovate for integration tests
Issues.Body:
the package.json in these tests points to file:dist/packages-dist which
is not materialized on renovate-bot, so the bot freaks out and fails to
update the lock files.

This means that the bot currently just opens up PRs that can't be merged.

Example: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/34071

(In the past this worked nicely because we didn't keep the yarn.lock files
in the git repo for these projects, but that had a problem with unpined
depenedencies and undeterministic build/test runs).

For now it's better to disable the bot by removing all the package.jsons
from the config. We should revisit this in the future have the bot update
the root package.json instead.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "ci: disable renovate for integration tests" (#34074)

Failed: Uncaught (in promise): TypeError: Cannot read property 'templateUrl' of null
TypeError: Cannot read property 'templateUrl' of null
    at componentNeedsResolution (http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js:21097:1)
    at maybeQueueResolutionOfComponentResources (http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js:21080:1)
    at compileComponent (http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js:39395:1)
    at http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/testing.js:1941:30
    at Set.forEach ()
    at R3TestBedCompiler.compileTypesSync (http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/testing.js:1932:1)
    at R3TestBedCompiler. (http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/testing.js:1827:1)
    at Generator.next ()
    at http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/tslib/tslib.es6.js:73:1
    at new ZoneAwarePromise (http://localhost:9876/_karma_webpack_/node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone-evergreen.js:872:1)
## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
@angular/core": "9.0.0-rc.3
**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: In Ivy, SkipSelf() is not accessing the parent's ViewContainerRef, ElementRef, etc
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by Angular Ivy ### Description Before Ivy, I was able to access the `ViewContainerRef`, `ElementRef`, etc of the parent directive using the `@SkipSelf` decorator in the child directive. With Ivy integrated in my project, it's no longer skipping its own injections and accessing the ones in its parent. For example, I have the following code: In app.component.ts ```ts @Directive({ selector: '[parentDirective]' }) export class ParentDirective { constructor(private vc: ViewContainerRef){ console.log(vc.element); } } @Directive({ selector: '[childDirective]' }) export class ChildDirective { constructor(@SkipSelf() private vc: ViewContainerRef){ console.log(vc.element); } } ``` in app.component.html ```html
parent child
``` These two directive classes should log the same ViewContainerRef element. However, with Ivy, you can see that's no longer the case. Here is the [reproduction](https://ivy.ng-run.com/edit/xMfu7xoF1t4b8hFvoU9N?open=app%2Fapp.component.html). This reproduction is made in Angular Ivy 8.1.0-next.3. But I also see this behavior in my project that's on "@angular/core": "9.0.0-rc.3", ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction [Minimal Reproduction](https://ivy.ng-run.com/edit/xMfu7xoF1t4b8hFvoU9N?open=app%2Fapp.component.html) ## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 


"@angular/core": "9.0.0-rc.3",
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "In Ivy, SkipSelf() is not accessing the parent's ViewContainerRef, ElementRef, etc" (#34066)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): i18n - ensure that escaped chars are handled in localized s…
Issues.Body:
…trings

When creating synthesized tagged template literals, one must provide both
the "cooked" text and the "raw" (unparsed) text. Previously there were no
good APIs for creating the AST nodes with raw text for such literals.
Recently the APIs were improved to support this, and they do an extra
check to ensure that the raw text parses to be equal to the cooked text.

It turns out there is a bug in this check -
see https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/35374.

This commit works around the bug by synthesizing a "head" node and morphing
it by changing its `kind` into the required node type.

// FW-1747
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): i18n - ensure that escaped chars are handled in localized s…" (#34065)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): support inserting a `viewRef` that is already present
Issues.Body:
When inserting a `viewRef` it is possible to not provide
an `index`, which is regarded as appending to the end of
the container.

If the `viewRef` already exists in the container, then
this results in a move. But there was a fault in the logic
that computed where to insert the `viewRef` that did not
account for the fact that the `viewRef` was already in
the container, so the insertion `index` was outside the
bounds of the array.

Fixes #33924
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): support inserting a `viewRef` that is already present" (#34052)

Issues.Title: SW registrationStrategy observable factory function parameters
Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

Oh hi there! 😄 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅-->


# 🚀 feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: --> This feature request is for @angular/service-worker


### Description


A [registrationStrategy](https://angular.io/api/service-worker/SwRegistrationOptions#registrationStrategy) factory function has a signature of `() => Observable<unknown>`
Would be handy to inject parameters like services or ngrx store to grab the observable.
The same way how prover factories works.


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ✍️--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.


### Describe alternatives you've considered

My usecase is to postpone service worker initialization until redirected from oauth2 flow. I was considering using `registerWithDelay` with sufficient amount of time but that's feels like a dirty solution. Much better solution would be to create an observable that fires when oauth service receives access token. (Hence app is after redirect and ready to boot service worker). For that I need to inject a service into factory function which is now not possible.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SW registrationStrategy observable factory function parameters" (#34064)

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): error in ivy when inheriting a ctor from an undecorated base
Issues.Body:
**Note:** this is a resubmit of https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/31271. I took the code from the original PR, rebased it against master, fixed the unit test failures and addressed the PR feedback. Sorry @alxhub, but for some reason the ownership of the original commit was switched when I rebased it. My changes are isolated to the second `fixup` commit.

--------------------------

Angular View Engine uses global knowledge to compile the following code:

```typescript
export class Base {
  constructor(private vcr: ViewContainerRef) {}
}

@Directive({...})
export class Dir extends Base {
  // constructor inherited from base
}
```

Here, `Dir` extends `Base` and inherits its constructor. To create a `Dir`
the arguments to this inherited constructor must be obtained via dependency
injection. View Engine is able to generate a correct factory for `Dir` to do
this because via metadata it knows the arguments of `Base`'s constructor,
even if `Base` is declared in a different library.

In Ivy, DI is entirely a runtime concept. Currently `Dir` is compiled with
an ngDirectiveDef field that delegates its factory to `getInheritedFactory`.
This looks for some kind of factory function on `Base`, which comes up
empty. This case looks identical to an inheritance chain with no
constructors, which works today in Ivy.

Both of these cases will now become an error in this commit. If a decorated
class inherits from an undecorated base class, a diagnostic is produced
informing the user of the need to either explicitly declare a constructor or
to decorate the base class.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(ivy): error in ivy when inheriting a ctor from an undecorated base" (#34061)

Issues.Title: Can't add routes dynamically to lazy (at runtime) loaded module (ivy)
Issues.Body: # 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/router ### Is this a regression? I don't know ### Description I just got a angular library loader working with a plain `import()`: ```ts loadPlugin(plugin: ProcusPlugin): Promise { return import('../../assets/plugins/users') .then(module => { if (!module[this.moduleName]) { console.warn(`Module ${this.moduleName} not found in Plugin ${this.modulePath}`); return null; } return module; }, error => null) .then(moduleOrFactory => { if (moduleOrFactory instanceof NgModuleFactory) { return moduleOrFactory[this.moduleName]; } else { return this.compiler.compileModuleAsync(moduleOrFactory[this.moduleName]); } }) .then(factory => { if (factory) { const routes = (factory.moduleType as any).routes; let children: ProcusRoutes; if (routes) { children = routes; } // component: factory.moduleType['UsersComponent'], // children, const route: ProcusRoute = { title: 'Test', icon: ['fas', 'angry'], path: `${this.moduleName}`, loadChildren: () => factory.moduleType, pathMatch: 'full', data: { pluginRoute: true } }; this.routingService.registerRoute(route); } }); } ``` But now I have another problem with the routing. All plugins (even the administration module, where the plugins are available) are lazy loaded: app.module.ts ```ts export const APP_ROUTES: ProcusRoutes = [ { path: '', component: AppComponent }, { path: 'auth', loadChildren: () => import('./authentication/authentication.module').then(m => m.AuthenticationModule) }, { path: 'admin', loadChildren: () => import('./administration/administration.module').then(m => m.AdministrationModule), title: 'Administration' }, { path: '**', redirectTo: '404' }, ]; ``` administration.module.ts: ```ts const routes: ProcusRoutes = [ { path: '', component: AdministrationComponent, children: [ { title: 'Dashboard', path: 'dashboard', icon: ['fas', 'home'], loadChildren: () => import('./dashboard/dashboard.module').then(m => m.DashboardModule) }, { title: 'Shootings', icon: ['fas', 'camera'], path: 'shootings', redirectTo: 'dashboard' }, { title: 'Photos', icon: ['fas', 'images'], path: 'photos', redirectTo: 'dashboard' }, // { title: 'Users', icon: ['fas', 'users'], path: 'users', redirectTo: 'dashboard' }, { title: 'Forum', icon: ['fas', 'comments'], path: 'forum', redirectTo: 'dashboard' }, { title: 'Login', icon: ['fas', 'lock'], path: 'auth/login', redirectTo: 'dashboard' }, { title: '404', icon: ['fas', 'exclamation-triangle'], path: '404', redirectTo: 'dashboard' }, { title: 'Test', icon: ['fas', 'vial'], path: 'test-content', component: TestContentComponent }, { title: 'Configuration', icon: ['fas', 'cog'], path: 'config', component: TestContentComponent }, { title: 'Plugins', path: 'plugins', icon: ['fas', 'plug'], loadChildren: () => import('../plugins/plugins.module').then(m => m.PluginsModule) }, // { path: '**', title: 'Not found', component: NotFoundComponent }, ], }, ]; ``` When I load a plugin, I inject a new route into the routes of the `administration.module.ts` in my `routing.service.ts`, where `registerRoute` is the entry: ```ts public registerRoute(route: ProcusRoute) { if (this.routes) { if (this.routeIsRegistered(route.path)) { return; } const baseRouteArray = this.routes[0].children; const newRouteIndex = baseRouteArray.push(route); const fallthroughRouteIndex = baseRouteArray.findIndex(item => item.path == '**'); baseRouteArray.swap(fallthroughRouteIndex, newRouteIndex); this.updateRouteConfig(this.routes); } } private routeIsRegistered(path: string) { if (!this.routes) { return false; } return this.routes.filter(r => r.path.toLowerCase() === path.toLowerCase()).length > 0; } private updateRouteConfig(config) { HOW CAN I UPDATE THIS ROUTE? this.routesChanged$.next(config); } private unRegisterRoute(path: string) { console.log('Unregister', path); this.updateRouteConfig(this.router.config.filter(route => route.path !== path)); } ``` `ProcusRoutes` is only an extended `Route` with some additional metadata of me: ```ts import { Route } from '@angular/router'; export interface ProcusRoute extends Route { title?: string; icon?: string[]; children?: ProcusRoutes; } export declare type ProcusRoutes = ProcusRoute[]; ``` The new route is added correct and the application shows me it in the navigation. But I can't get the new routing working. I already modified `_loadedConfig` but it seems that this doesn't reload the config and `router.resetConfig` doesn't reload the lazy routes. Every plugin has an entry route with siblings or children which should be called when I click on the newly added route: user.plugin.module: ```ts import { NgModule } from '@angular/core'; import { RouterModule } from '@angular/router'; import { UsersComponent } from './users.component'; export const routes = [ { path: '', component: UsersComponent, title: 'Test', icon: ['fas', 'angry'] }, ]; @NgModule({ declarations: [UsersComponent], imports: [ RouterModule.forChild(routes) ], exports: [UsersComponent], entryComponents: [UsersComponent] }) export class UsersModule { static entry = UsersComponent; public readonly routes = routes; } ``` There is no way to force Angular to rebuild the entire url tree to get the updated routes from the `administration.module` ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-sfhjhr ## 🔥 Exception or Error n/a ## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** Angular 8.0.0 **Anything else relevant?** How can I add a route to the entire router tree for a lazy loaded module? There is a private `_loadedConfig` with correspondending items but changing a private property is pretty ugly. I'm pretty unsure if this is a bug or just not supported. Intention of this is, that I want to load angular libraries at runtime (they are my plugins).

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): switch to license-checker-webpack-plugin
Issues.Body:
Fixes #16193.

This replaces the existing `license-webpack-plugin` with the new `license-checker-webpack-plugin`. The former would output multiple `3rdpartylicenses.txt` files which would trigger warnings in Webpack. The later does not emit this warning and still appears to log all third party licenses in a reasonable fashion.

The output format is changed, see https://www.diffchecker.com/puCPV7LQ for a more complete before-and-after comparison of a simple example Angular app (with jQuery and Bootstrap installed).

It is worth discussing if we want to go down this route or if we should stick with `license-webpack-plugin` and attempt to fix it rather than changing the entire dependency.

Issues.Title: Using build works, build --prod fails with intl-messageformat
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No ### Description I've added intl-messageformat to the project and copied and pasted their example code. serve and build work fine. Build --prod works fine with Chrome, however build --prod with the `optimisation: true` fails in IE (and in Chrome if forced to use the es5 files). I have added `commonChunk: false` to the angular.json build config. And added the intl-pluralrules polyfill to the polyfills file. ``` "intl-messageformat": "^7.6.0", "intl-pluralrules": "^1.1.1" ``` I've created a repo here https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-p1cyli ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction `ng build --prod` serve the dist project in IE11 and look for the error in the console. ## 🔥 Exception or Error IE11

Issues.Title: Spec (tests) maintenance aid
Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

Oh hi there! 😄

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅-->


# 🚀 Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
 The CLI has scaffolding spec file capability and along with that is missing the functionality to:
 * **create** spec for an existing component 
 * **update** existing spec file ("read" deps out of class-under-test and scaffold test deps in the spec file)


### Describe the solution you'd like
Creating and maintaining tests is a chore. And it seems that gives one more reason people not to do it. But we can help alleviate some of that and have people writing the tests and not the boilerplate.

Given the class under test file CLI could : (`ng g spec components/my.component.ts`)
 * read the dependencies - using Typescript and getting names and types of deps
 * generate spec file - using schematics 
 * update existing spec files - using a mixture of the above two

An implementation can be found here https://github.com/gparlakov/scuri (VS Code extension https://github.com/gparlakov/scuri-code). It supports: 
 * create spec for existing Typescript class
 * update existing spec  (including CLI generated spec)
 * generate autospy function to aid in mocks - [here](https://github.com/gparlakov/scuri/blob/master/src/autospy/files/jasmine/auto-spy.ts.template)


### Describe alternatives you've considered
After talking with @mgechev among other people, I'd like to start a discussion and see:
 * is this is as big of a problem as I see it?
 * do we fix it "inside" of CLI or "outside"?

# 🚀 Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ x] build
- [ x] serve
- [x ] test

- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
Currently assets array allows glob with input path, however input path itself does not support wildcards.
Like ./node_modules/@myscope/**/assets/i18n/*
Where ** is any number of unknown libraries (like shared, services, featureabc).

With glob it would also create every folder between @myscope to assets/i18n, instead of copying just the contents of i18n.

### Describe the solution you'd like
The input path allows wildcards to set the root or a flag to only copy contents of the glob result path.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Node scripts that requires extra steps and wouldn't know if project output is different from dist and it does not work with serve.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix budget checks
Issues.Body:
Fixes #15792.

This turned out to be a little more complicated than expected due to the combination of a few different problems resulting in broken budget checks.

* File sizes were previously computed in a Webpack plugin, which is executed during certain lifecycle hooks. I needed to move this to run *after* the build when all the necessary file size information is known. The first commit refactors the size computations without any significant changes to the output.
* Files listed as `lazy: true` or `inject: false` in the app dev's `angular.json` file were included in the `initial` bundle, even though these resources must be loaded asynchronously. The second commit filters out files which were marked asynchronous from the `initial` bundle.
* Differential builds were included in the same size, so the `main` size was including both the ES2015 **and** ES5 sizes together, which isn't what the user would want. The third commit updates the relevant budgets to output two sizes, one for each differential build, rather than including them together.

I made separate commits performing each of these steps individually to make the logic a little easier to follow and understand.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix budget checks" (#16268)

Issues.Title: fix(google-maps): handle trying to access the map before it has been initialized
Issues.Body: As things are set up at the moment, the Google `Map` object will be initialized once the API has loaded, however all of the methods on the `GoogleMap` component assume that the object will always be defined. This means that if any of the methods are called before it is initialized, we'll throw a null pointer error. These changes add a more readable error so people know what to do.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(google-maps): handle trying to access the map before it has been initialized" (#17805)

Issues.Title: fix(dialog): use view container from config when attaching content
Issues.Body: Currently we only use the specified `ViewContainerRef` to attach the dialog container, but not the content itself. We couldn't fix this until now due to the bug that was fixed by #17731.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(dialog): use view container from config when attaching content" (#17819)

Issues.Title: fix(material/tree): Apply aria-level to all nodes
Issues.Body:
Previously, only leaf nodes had aria-level applied.

This is an incremental change since this is an unfamiliar codebase for
me. The main benefit it will have on its own is that it will allow
anyone doing custom dom manipulation to know what level the node is on.
Otherwise by itself there is no change in how NVDA reads nodes with
children. (It currently reads them as literally "grouping"; no
information about the contents is provided).

This change will be necessary for a later change I'm planning, wherein
the role of parent nodes will be changed from "group" to "treeitem", in
accordance with how roles are applied in WAI-ARIA reference examples
such as
https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices/examples/treeview/treeview-1/treeview-1b.html
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/tree): Apply aria-level to all nodes" (#17818)

Issues.Title: fix(input): avoid multiple autosize input listeners with ivy
Issues.Body: Avoids double event listeners for the Material autosize directive, because Ivy merges inherited metadata, whereas ViewEngine overrides. We've made similar fixes in other places, but we probably missed this one because it doesn't break anything.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(input): avoid multiple autosize input listeners with ivy" (#17817)

Issues.Title: [MatTable] ViewChildren returns MatRow in incorrect order if you add new rows in the middle of the table
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-rhyhnz?file=app/app.component.ts
2. Click "Add Element button"
3. Verify displayed rows - it's inserted in the middle of the table
4. Check console with ViewChildren log - it inserts in the end of query list.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

ViewChildren for mat table rows should return data in according to the table model and view.


#### Actual Behavior

When you add new row to the mat table in random place ViewChildren always adds it to the end


#### Environment

- Angular: Google
- CDK/Material: Google
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Google Chrome

Issues.Title: Error on material dynamic tree example
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
'@Injectable()' annotation position

#### What is the current behavior?
There is an '@Injectable()' annotation above 'DynamicDataSource'

#### What is the expected behavior?

https://material.angular.io/components/tree/examples

Updates to the latest rules_nodejs version. Releases often involve a lot of changes, so we don't want to fall behind too much.

**Note**: Mostly dependenices have changed into peer dependencies. I find it weird that we currently mix up SystemJS and RequireJS. Issues.Title: mat-form-field with appearance set to outline throws type error on older browsers
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the [form-field example page](https://material.angular.io/components/form-field/overview) on Edge <= v22
Note: the behavior has been fixed in the current version of Edge (v24 at the time of writing)
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
No type errors.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
`stack: "TypeError: Object doesn't support property or method 'Symbol.iterator' at t.prototype.updateOutlineGap..."`

I believe the error is originating from [this line of code](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/b56bcadaeaf2420c7a0e3dac429f47e67a058bee/src/material/form-field/form-field.ts#L562), and could probably be fixed by changing it to:

`for (const child of Array.from(labelEl.children)) {...`
or
`Array.prototype.forEach.call(labelEl.children, function (child) {...`


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.0
- CDK/Material: 8.1.2
- Browser(s): MS Edge 42
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-form-field with appearance set to outline throws type error on older browsers" (#17810)

Issues.Title: Scroll event not fired with mat-sort-header
Issues.Body:
Hi all!

I've got a very weird issue. I'm showing data to the user with a table format and the matSort module. When I have the mat-sort-header atrribute added to a header, the scroll event is not fired at all times. The wheel event is however always fired.

This results in the window not scrolling (getting stuck). When you drag the scrollbar manually, the scroll is working again. However the time it stays working is shorter after manual scrolling.

#### Reproduction

I've tried to reproduce this on stackblitz, but can't reproduce it. While inserting my dataset in the example, everything keeps working.

When inserting the stackblitz example in our application, the bug still remains...
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

While scrolling the page, the scroll event should always be fired


#### Actual Behavior

The scroll event suddenly stops firing. The wheel event is still being fired...


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.3
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Scroll event not fired with mat-sort-header" (#17807)

Issues.Title: Cannot read property 'viewContainer' of undefined in CdkTree Angular 9 RC3
Issues.Body:
Since upgrading to Angular 9 RC3, I'm seeing the following exception when creating a CDK Tree:

```
core.js:6068 ERROR TypeError: Cannot read property 'viewContainer' of undefined
    at CdkTree.renderNodeChanges (tree.js:730)
    at SafeSubscriber._next (tree.js:716)
    at SafeSubscriber.__tryOrUnsub (Subscriber.js:183)
    at SafeSubscriber.next (Subscriber.js:122)
    at Subscriber._next (Subscriber.js:72)
    at Subscriber.next (Subscriber.js:49)
    at TakeUntilSubscriber._next (Subscriber.js:72)
    at TakeUntilSubscriber.next (Subscriber.js:49)
    at Observable._subscribe (subscribeToArray.js:3)
    at Observable._trySubscribe (Observable.js:42)
```

This is caused by the _nodeOutlet property on the CdkTree being undefined.



#### Environment

- Angular: 9 RC 3
- CDK/Material: 9 RC 4
- Browser(s): Chrome 78
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Cannot read property 'viewContainer' of undefined in CdkTree Angular 9 RC3" (#17806)

Issues.Title: Checkbox: UI bug when implementing "select all" functionality
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
This is simply a fork of the example for adding checkboxes to a table from the docs. The only thing I changed was I added the ELEMENT_DATA as the initial selected value to simulate the case in which all rows start out as checked.

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-vxmvu6?file=src/app/table-selection-example.ts
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

I should be able to select/deselect rows


#### Actual Behavior
The "select all" checkbox displays a bug for a split second. To replicate the bug simply deselect any of the rows but look at the "select all" checkbox, it'll turn to unchecked instead of indeterminate for a brief second, then it will correctly settle on indeterminate. 

I've noticed this bug only occurs the first time, and it'll also not occur if your first action is to toggle "select all" instead of any of the rows. 

I am also positive the bug is not from the cdk as I had initially implemented this without the the cdk collection helper, and that's when I came across the error.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Checkbox: UI bug when implementing "select all" functionality" (#17794)
